editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ADMONITION TO THE NOBILITY AND PEOPLE OF ENGLAND AND IRELAND CONCERNINGE THE PRESENT VVARRES made for the execution of his Holines Sentence, by the highe and mightie Kinge Catholike of Spaine.
By the CARDINAL of Englande.
Ao. M. D. LXXXVIII.

div.p:
RIghte honorable wor≈øhipfull and mo≈øte dearelie beloued in our lorde, no man can be ignorante that eyther by reporte, readinge, or remeÃÑbrance, li≈øt looke backe, not muche further theÃÑ fiftie yeares pa≈øte, that this great mi≈øerie, and mutation of ≈øtate and ReligioÃÑ in this our realme of England by which our Churche (Alas) ys already ouerthrowne, our cuntrie in extreame tearmes of peri≈øhinge, and our ≈øelues with what ≈øo euer is deare vuto vs, in daily dreade of de≈øtructioÃÑ and damnation proceaded not fir≈øte of the ≈øubiectes di≈øorder or di≈øobedience to theire kinges (as els where Here≈øie often dothe) and as we ≈øee in many of the next nations vnto vs yt pre≈øently hapneth, where popular mutenie again≈øt theire magi≈øtrates, hath cau≈øed their like calamity: But begonne fir≈øte and wholly in effecte, by our Kinge that then was, Henrie the eighte, and afterwarde till this daie, hathe bene ≈øpecially pur≈øued, by
our princes preten≈øed lawes, and v≈øurped ≈øouerainty ouer our ≈øoules, to the which our Nobilit√©, Prie≈øtes and people, by force and feare, haue rather bene drawne then by lawful con≈øente yeilded therunto.

lob. 14. And albeit wicked and hipocriticall kinges, be ≈øuffred ≈øumtimes or ≈øent from God, for the ≈øubiectes ≈øinnes and for our offences, greate no doubte and greauous in euerie e≈øtate (let none excu≈øe them≈øelues, let none accu≈øe others;) and that we hereby, may worthely al≈øo be thought to haue de≈øerued bothe our princes fall, and our 1. Reg. 13. owne puni≈øhement, accordinge to Gods mo≈øt holy coÃÑmination, that when his people ≈øhould cea≈øe to ≈øerue him in truthe, and comitt wickednes, bothe they & theire kinge ≈øhoulde peri≈øhe together: Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, to ≈øee and knowe the place ≈øpecially affected, and the nexte immediate ≈øurge of all our ≈øores‚ñ™ where we expecte remedy and not ruine, ys nece≈ø≈øary for our recouery. VVherin, though the ca≈øe haue longe ≈øemed vvel neere de≈øperate, yet God him≈øelf not forget full of his olde mercies, beholdinge from heauen our not voluntary but coacted mi≈øeries, and our mo≈øte holy and zelous father in Chri≈øte Sixtus the fifte, his highe≈øte Mini≈øter, and our chefe≈øt magi≈øtrate and ma≈øter in earthe, to whom our Sauiour hath giuen Apo≈øtolike power to take vengeance vpon di≈øobedience, moued by the ≈øorowes and ≈øighes of ≈øo manie aflicted ≈øoules, and in≈øtant praiers of all Chri≈øtian people that pittie our enforced peri≈øhinge in Schi≈øme and Here≈øie, doth giue vs at this time, both better meanes, more hope, and redyer helpe, then we
coulde euer po≈øsiblie haue either de≈øerued or de ≈øired: yea thei haue (not the pope alone but God him≈øel≈øt ≈øuerly, and other the mo≈øt zelous and mightie≈øt Princes in Chri≈øtendom by his Induction) takeÃÑ the whole care of our ca≈øe into their owne handes, and that with ≈øuche ≈øinceare intention (whereof my-≈øelf can be≈øt beare witnes and a≈ø≈øure you my deare cuntrymen) and in ≈øuch ≈øweete moderate & mercifull ≈øorte, that in the appliance of the prepared remedie, neither the corps of our commonwealthe, nede to feele or feare any di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, nor any parte, (other then the principall affected, and ≈øum ≈øuche feawe as will not followe this offer of Gods ordinaunce) be wroonge or wrinched thereby. For albeit of ten els, in likeca≈øe of reuolte from Gods Churche and our fathers faithe, not onlie the kinges, but al≈øo their cuntries, after diuers dreadefull Cen≈øures and Sentences, haue bene by ≈øupreme authority of Chri≈øtes vicar, giuen vp to Inua≈øioÃÑ, warres, wa≈øtes, and final di≈øtruction, and we nowe mighte by way of rigor and extreame Iu≈øtice, be bothe charged & cha≈øti≈øed far more depely then the Churche of Theatira for tollerating Apo. 2. the wicked Ie≈øabell, not now as then callinge her≈øelf a propheti≈ø≈øe, but the verie cheefe ≈øpirituall gouerne≈ø≈øe vnder God, to teache and deceaue Gods ≈øeruantes, and to force them to fornication, to eate breade of Idolatrie in Schi≈ømati call ≈øeruice. And al≈øo for that, by error of coÃÑ≈øcience or wante of couragc, we haue ≈øo longe vnnaturally ≈øubdued our ≈øoules to our bodies, hazarded our eternall ≈øaluation, to ≈øaue our tran≈øitorie ≈øub≈øtance, obeyed man more then God, preferred
the temporall title, not only of lawful ciuill authority, but of manifold v≈øurped Tirannie, aboue the ≈øupreame Bi≈øhops ≈øpirituall ≈øoue Mat. 16. Io. vl ‚Ä¢ . raignty, by Chri≈øtes expre≈ø≈øe worde e≈øtabli≈øhed on earthe, yeilding to the one mo≈øte ≈øeruilly as to our hou≈øehold and home God, and as to a verie nationall idol, ≈øubiection bothe of bodie and ≈øoule, & thearby di≈øobeyinge, di≈øgraceynge di≈øpi ≈øinge, and bla≈øpheminge the other, as a forreÃÑ power, or rather as a ≈øtrange deuill or Antechri≈øte Deut. 17 Luc. 10. Num. 16. (a thinge puni≈øhable in the olde lawe by deathe reputed inthe newe for expre≈ø≈øe contempt of Chri≈øtes owne per≈øon, reuenged in Core and his confederates by fearefull fier from heauen, by horrible gapinge of the grounde they ≈øtoode vpon and by ≈øudden ≈øinkinge downe to hell.) Yet all this notwth≈øtandinge, the Popes holines, who accordinge to his Apo≈øtolike benignity, wholly inclined to mercy, followinge Gods rule and example rather of ≈øparinge the wicked for the good, then puni≈øhinge the innocent for the euil, that the ≈øoule which ≈øinneth onely may peri≈øhe, doth mo≈øt mercifully forget and forgiue all the premi≈ø≈øes, a≈øwell in the whole body of the coÃÑmoÃÑ wealthe as in euery particuler per≈øon, that ys penitent and wearie of the≈øe horrible di≈øorders and trea≈øons committed again≈øt God, the See Apo≈øtolike, holie Churche, and our cuntrie (incorrigible per≈øons, and principall procurers of the≈øe mi≈øchefs only excepted) and only meaneth in Chri≈øtes woorde and power giuen vnto him, and in zeale of Gods hou≈øe, to pur≈øue the actuall depriuation, of Elizabethe the preten≈øed Queene, eft≈øones declared and iuditially ≈øenten≈øed,
by his Holines predece≈ø≈øors, PIVS QVINTVS and GREGORIE the XIII. for an heretike and v≈øurper‚ñ™ and the proper pre≈øent cau≈øe of perdition of millions of ≈øoules at home, and the verie bane of all Chri≈øtian kingdomes and ≈øtates neere aboute her. That in this one womans condigne correction, Gods mighty arme that depo≈øeth the proude and powrable per≈øons froÃÑ their Luc. 1. ≈øeates may be feared and glorified, and the horrible and wicked outrages of Henrie the eighte her ≈øuppo≈øed fathers hou≈øe and per≈øon, together with Gods vengeance on the ≈øame, may in ≈øum mea≈øure of his iu≈øtice be accompli≈øhed, and our whole people put in happy hope of ≈øaluatioÃÑ and full fredom of con≈øcience againe, that all the P≈øal. 5 ‚Ä¢
iu≈øte of the earthe may ≈øaie. Lo this is ≈øhe that tooke not God for her ≈øtrenghte, but tru≈øted to her trea≈øures and preuailed in her wickednes. And that all the worlde, and namely our owne nation and people, to whom the matter ≈øo nearly apperteineth, may throughly iudge a≈øwell of this womans and her parentes de ‚Ä¢ ertes, as of his Holines and his mightie and godly confederates mo≈øte happie intention; and howe iu≈øtelie and nedefullie for our only benefi ‚Ä¢ e and ≈øuccour, they procede at this pre≈øent to her cha≈øti≈øement and depo≈øition; Yt may plea≈øe all my mo≈øt deere cuntrymen‚ñ™ and ≈øpecialy our peeres and Nobilitie, on whom the auncyent honor and libertie of our churche and cuntrie cheifely dependethe, and by who≈øe ≈øworde and kinghtehood (≈øpecially giuen to them and theire noble progenitors for defence of the Catholike religion) our cuntrie hathe often bene deliuered from the tyranny
and vexation of diuers di≈øordered in≈øupportable kinges and cruell v≈øurpers. May it plea≈øe them (I ≈øaie) to con≈øider but alitle with me, the condition of the per≈øon pur≈øued, and cen≈øured by Gods Churche, together with the weight, qualety, & number of her offences, and horrible crimes, which beinge open almo≈øte to all the worlde before, and now brefely recorded by this writinge, no man (I tru≈øte) ≈øhall maruell why Chri≈øtes vicar here in earthe, with other highe mini≈øters of Gods iu≈øtice, wolde or could depriue this tirante of her v≈øurped ≈øtate and dominion, when no commonwealthe by lawe of nature nether wolde nor mighte iu≈øtelie ≈øuffer any ≈øuche, to rule or raigne ouer any humane ≈øocietie, thoughe neither Chri≈øte, Pope, fayth, nor religion were knowne.

The chee ≈øe poinctes of this admonitioÃÑ. To procede therfore brefely and plainely we will ≈øett downe what manner of womaÃÑ ≈øhe ys again≈øt whom this holie enterpri≈øe ys made; of whom and in what maÃÑner di≈ø≈øended; Howe intruded into that dignity wherin ≈øhe ≈øtandeth; Howe ≈øhe hath behaued her≈øelf both at home and abrode; By what lawes of God and man her puni≈øhement ys pur≈øued; Howe iu≈øte, hone≈øt, and nece≈ø≈øarie cau≈øes all true Engli≈øhmen haue to embrace & ≈øett forward the ≈øame, ≈øeing yt procedeth from ≈øo lawfull authorite, ≈øo iu≈øt groundes, ≈øo holie intentions, and tendeth to ≈øo happie an ende, and is to be executed by ≈øo ≈øuer and ≈øweete meanes, and cho≈øen per≈øons, as now ≈øhall be declared.

And fir≈øt of all it is notorious to the whole worlde, that Henrie the ≈øuppo≈øed father to this
preten≈øed Queene, be≈øides the infinite quantety and enormeous qualety, of his mo≈øt execrable wickednes, for the which by all lawe of religioÃÑ, rea≈øon, & nature, he de≈øerued often times to be depriued, was in fine, for his horrible ≈øacriledges, murtheringe of Saintes, and rebellioÃÑ again≈øt Gods Churche, lawfully excommunicated and depriued by Paulus tertius in the yeare 1535‚ñ™ and there withall by name and in particuler all the i≈ø≈øue that ≈øhould procede of his ince≈øtuous copulation with Anne Bullen, was mo≈øte iu≈øtly declared illegitimate and vncapable of ≈øucce≈øsion to the croune of England: and that a≈øwell by the ≈øentence of the ≈øaid Paule, and of his predece≈ø≈øor Clement the VII. in the yeare of our lorde 1533. (bothe which ≈øtande in theire full force ≈øtill) as by ≈øundry actes of parliament made by Henry him ≈øelf and neuer repealed legitimating her ≈øi≈øter and declaringe her to be ba≈øe, ≈øhe mu≈øt nedes be adiudged by lawe & nature vnable to inherite the croune.

Neyther may ≈øhe here alege, that by con≈øent of the ≈øtates and Commonwelthe ≈øhe ys lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed: for that by force ≈øhe intruded, and con≈øtreyned many men to giue theire con≈øentes, depo≈øinge vniu≈øtly the Lordes of the Clergy without whome no lawfull Parlament can be holden in that Realme, nor Statute made which hath force to authori≈øe Prince or binde Subiectes. Ouer and be≈øides that ≈øhe neuer had con≈øente nor any approbation of the See Apo≈øtolike, without which, ≈øhe nor any other can be lawfull Kinge or Quene of Englande, by rea≈øon of the auncyent Acorde, made betwene
AlexaÃÑder the. III. the yere 1171. and HeÃÑry the II. then kinge when he was ab≈øolued for the deathe of ≈øainte Thomas of CaÃÑterburie that no maÃÑ might lawfully take that Crowne nor be accoÃÑ pted as Kinge, till he were confirmed by the ≈øoueraigne Pa≈øtor of our ≈øoules which for the time ≈øhoulde be: This accorde afterwardes beinge renewed, aboute the yere 1210. by Kinge Iohn, who confirmed the ≈øame by othe to Pandulphus the Pope his legate, at the ≈øpeciall reque≈øte and procurement of the Lordes and Comons, as a thinge mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for pre≈øeruatioÃÑ of the Realme from vniu≈øt v≈øurpation of Tyrantes, and auoydinge other incoÃÑueniences which they had proued, and mighte ea≈øely fall againe by the di≈øorder of ≈øome wicked Kinge.

But how≈øoeuer ≈øhe be di≈ø≈øended or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the croune, her manifolde wickednes hath ben, ≈øo heinous and intollerable that for the ≈øame ≈øhe hathe bene in per≈øon iu≈øtly depo≈øed by the ≈øentences of thre ≈øundrie Popes, wherunto yf we adde the two former cen≈øures condemninge her ince≈øtuous natiuity and generatioÃÑ, we ≈øhall finde that ≈øhe hathe ben condeÃÑned by fiue declaratorie iuditiall ≈øenteÃÑces of Gods Churche.

Per≈øonable crimes of Elizabeth, and fir≈øt of Here≈øie. And to beginne with the highe≈øt and mo≈øt heinou≈øe crime of all again≈øt God and his Churche, ≈øhe ys conuicted of many damnable here≈øies, and open rebellion again≈øt Gods Churche and See Apo≈øtolike, for which ≈øhe ys ≈øo notoriou≈øly knowne, termed and taken for an heretike, a≈øwell at home as abrode, that ≈øhe was glad to prouide by a ≈øpecial acte of parliament, that none ≈øhould call her heritike, Schi≈ømatike, Tyrante,
v≈øurper, or infidell, vnder paine of highe trea≈øon.

She arrogateth ≈øpirtiuall dignite. She v≈øurpeth by Luciferian pride, the title of ≈øupreme Eccle≈øia≈øticall gouernment, a thinge in a woman, in all mens memory vnheard of, nor tollerable to the ma≈øtres of her owne ≈øecte, and to Catholikes in the world mo≈øt ridiculous, ab≈øurde, mon≈øtrous, dete≈øtable, and a verie fable to the po≈øterite.

Ba≈øtardie. She vnlawfully intruded her≈øelf, as before I haue ≈øaid, in to po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of the croune of England, and the annexed dominions not by any di≈ø≈øent of inheritannce or other lawfull title, but only by enforced vniu≈øt partly made by her ≈øuppo≈øed father beinge then an excommunicated per≈øon, and partely coacted by her≈øelf and her coplices in the beginninge of her pretended raigne, beinge indede taken and knowen for an ince≈øtuons ba≈øtard, begotten and borne in ≈øinne, of an infamous curte≈øan Anne Bullen, after warde executed for aduoutery, trea≈øon, here≈øie and ince≈øte, amoÃÑge≈øt others with her owne naturall brother, which Anne, her ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed father kepte by preten≈øed mariage‚ñ™ in the life of his law full wife, the mo≈øt renonmed and ble≈ø≈øed ladie Queene Katherine, daughter of Ca≈øtill and Ara gon, as he did before vnnaturally knovve and ke pe bothe the ≈øaid Annes mother and ≈øi≈øter.

Periury and impiety. She ys guilty of periury and highe impietie for that ≈øhe did breake, violate, and deride, the ≈øollemne othe and promi≈øe made in her coronation, for defence of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall liberties and priuileges graunted by the auncieÃÑt Chri≈øtian kinges of our realme, and for the contempte
of the holy ceremony v≈øed in the annointinge and inue≈øtinge of all faithfull princes: wher in her wickednes was ≈øo notorious, that the principall Prelate that then was in the realme, and to whom by auncyent order (the Cardinall of Can terbury then being deade) that function apperteined, dur≈øt not for feare of God, and re≈øpect of his con≈øcience, nor did not annointe her.

Aboli≈ø≈øhinge Catholike Religion. She did immediately vpon her ≈øaid intru≈øioÃÑ, violentlie again≈øt all lavve and order (the whole Clergie, and many of the nobility and coÃÑmons con≈øtantlie reclaminge) to the predition of infinite ≈øoules, aboli≈ø he the whole Catholike Religion, and faithe, that all the former faithefull kin ges of our cuntrie honorably liued and died in; repealinge at the ≈øame time all the godly actes that Queene Marie the onlie lavvfull daughter of Kinge Henrie the eighte, made for the reconcilement of the realme, to the vnite of Gods vniuer≈øall Churche againe; and reuyued all the impious ≈øtatutes, made by her for≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed father and brother again≈øte God, the Churche, the See Apo≈øtolike, & all innocencie, by which ≈øhe ≈øeuered her≈øelf and ≈øubiectes violently from the ≈øocietie of all Catholike cuntries, and from the felovv≈øhip of all faithefull princes and prei≈øtes in the worlde.

Prophaninge Sacramentes. She did at the ≈øame time aboli≈øh or prophane all the holie ≈øacramentes of Chri≈øtes Churche, and aboue other in particuler, the very ble≈ø≈øed and ≈øoueraine facrifice of Chri≈øtes bodie and blud, errectinge for the ≈øame, and in di≈øgrace therof, highe idolatrie, and poluted breade of ≈øchi≈øme and abhominable de≈øolation.

Forbiddinge preachers. She did ≈øhutt vp bothe pulpits and Churches from all Catholike prei≈øtes, preachers, and people, cau≈øed all Gods publike trew auncyent honor, ≈øeruice, and ≈øollemnity, throughout the whole realme of England (a mo≈øte lameÃÑtable ca≈øe) and not longe after in Ireland, to cea≈øe vpon one daie, con≈øtrayninge by greate penalties and extreme puni≈øhment many thovv≈øand poore chri≈øtian ≈øoules of euery degree and ≈øexe, to for≈øake that faith and religioÃÑ, in which they and all theire forfathers were bapti≈øed and brought vp, euer ≈øince the realme was fir≈øt conuerted‚ñ™ to Chri≈øte, to the great torment of theire mindes and coÃÑ ≈øciences and ≈øhortninge of theire daies.

Prophaninge of churches and all holies.
